StudentType.Description: Appreciates that the Developers will be able to deliver on his designs better, faster, cheaper
Autists quietly ask questions about material completely unrelated to what you are presenting. May be a type of Rain-Man.
Considers a Product Backlog item to be a pointer to a large specification document that defines both the what and the how; also known as "Specs"
The Blue Screen is the unlucky student whose computer just locks up or otherwise misbehaves. Usually walking over and standing near the computer fixes the problem.
The Career Changer is looking to make more money and heard that your industry can provide that. Career Changers are often sponges.
Wants to see a case study for everything (e.g. test first, pair programming, agile, working as a team, etc.); also known as a flat-earther
Knows Scrum but no one else on the team cares. The project is in trouble and Cassandra is the only one who sees it. She watches helplessly as it fails.
Considers this a valid development metric, even to be added to the DoD, and possibly as a team measurement
The Dinosaur is a type of "Know-It-All" with no modern experience, but believes 20+ years with dead tech still makes them an expert
As annoying as Jar-Jar, but with the ability to introduce substantially more waste into the process
Not truly engaged - just wants to be an instructor. Their questions are mostly meta - about the event or your background.
Scrum Master tries to help the team by redefining the DoD instead of addressing a real constraint, which makes things worse.
Uses deep knowledge for malicious or disruptive purposes; hides among the other students
Can't sit still, constantly moving or sighing; chairs will get negative feedback
Self-explanatory; may try to distract the instructor
Still uses the term "grooming" instead of "refinement" despite updates to the Scrum Guide
Believes a Sprint dedicated to hardening is required for release - why not 2 or 3?
Works ahead during lectures to leave early; may be a Know-It-All or Day-Planner
Points out your coding errors right after the IDE or parser already does
Self-explanatory; confidently answers questions incorrectly and often
Closed-minded evangelist for their favorite practice, process, or tech; tries to convert others
Already an "expert" in everything you teach (or so they believe); doesn't need the class
Calls Scrum a "methodology" and wants specific answers Scrum doesn't offer; also known as a "perma-shu"
Believes Scrum can't work for "mission critical" apps; prefers heavy upfront design
Attends primarily for the snacks, coffee, or raffle prizes
Sits far away, next to noisy devices, and asks questions no one can hear
Forced to attend the class; unmotivated and unengaged
A type of Prisoner - arms folded, emitting negative energy
Uses the term "QA" even after learning Scrum has no sub-teams
Answers questions that you asked an hour ago
Thinks Scrum works in class, but not in the "real world"; requires changes the rules
Calls people "resources" despite learning better, alternative language
Back-row student working remotely and billing hours during class
Everything ties back to their favorite tech stack; expect a product pitch
PMI-certified trying to self-organize teams around traditional metrics
Reads the Scrum Guide before bed - in multiple languages; also known as "Bradley"
Team members work in silos and never talk; Daily Scrum is the only (awkward) interaction
Always cold or hot. Wears layers. Constantly complains about room temperature
Dominates all discussions whether or not they know the topic; may be an Insurgent
Wants to learn everything. Constant questions, lots of notes. May also be a Xerox
Points out typos or errors of any size; also known as F7
Thinks you need a preparation Sprint for architecture, infrastructure, etc.
Calls the Daily Scrum a "standup" and thinks holding it equates to Professional Scrum
Participates, gets it, finishes activities early, gives great evals; your ideal student
Won't let you take breaks or eat without hanging with you and asking questions; may be a Doppelgänger
Enough said
Must preface every question or point with a long, unrelated story
Never makes eye contact - always surfing; may be a Road Warrior
Claims to know the future of tech; usually just a Dinosaur in disguise
Wants Scrum to help him make better decisions to manage the team better
Steals your punchlines or answers while you're still explaining
Asks questions about topics from earlier (or later) in the day/week
Loyal to the competitor's process or product; ready for battle - expect a debate
Believes stakeholders must approve done items - or Scrum won't work
Thinks "user story" = "use case"; has no clue what acceptance criteria are
Copies everything (verbatim); understanding optional
